content.rendered:
What is Native CMS? CMS is a rockin’ way to share updates, images, documents, articles, events, blog posts, and more within your Experience and Commerce sites! You get to not only share your own homegrown content, with granular sharing and approvals, but you get to have BEAUTIFUL list views available to make the content not only fabulous to share but truly shine to your users!

Types of CMS

We previously reviewed CMS Connect, and this post we are going to deep dive on Native CMS, second of the three CMS types available. Although each type of CMS has their records created somewhat differently, they all reunite in the Content Management area of the Community’s Experience Workspace. Here’s a quick high level on all 2 before we dig into Native CMS.

Salesforce CRM CMS/ Hybrid CMS

Hybrid CMS: This type of CMS allows for users to have a central creation location of Salesforce, and with that Salesforce powered DeLorean, I mean experience, they get to not only power their org (Eg Commerce, Experience, Marketing all included there), but also external systems resolve the challenges of coupled creation and presentation by dropping the presentation touchpoint, or presentation “head.” You use a headless CMS to create and modify the content, but the content is very much needed to feed into a separate presentation application.

Native CMS

Hybrid CMS: A native experience channel or touchpoint is provided by a hybrid CMS, but also gives you the flexibility to present content to any touchpoint built on a third-party system. 

CMS Connect

This is the CMS that allows you to bring in content from outside of Salesforce and display it internally. You can do this a few different ways:

  • First you can bring over JSON, like from a WordPress Site to display using the CMS Collection (JSON) component – check out the post how here
  • You can also bring over HTML from an outside source in the same way using the CMS Collection (HTML) component
  • Third, you can bring over your header and footer from another system to use in your community
  • In addition, what you bring can be javascript, JSON, CSS, or HTML.

Today Native CMS

Today we will be talking about setting up Native CMS and what that takes.

Where to Use

B2C Commerce Channels: To use your Salesforce CMS workspace content with B2C Commerce Page Designer, see Connect Salesforce CMS to Page Designer.

B2B Commerce Channels: To share Salesforce CMS content with the B2B Commerce managed package or in other Salesforce Tabs + Visualforce sites, see the Connect REST API Developer Guide and the Apex Developer Guide for more information. The content itself is still created and managed in the Salesforce CMS app.

Experience Cloud Site Channels: Use the Experience Cloud Content Delivery Network (CDN) to deliver Salesforce CMS content to your Experience Cloud site. A public channel allows you to readily connect content to custom applications.

Pardot Email Marketing and Templates: With a public channel, you can use our CDN partner, Akamai, or a CDN of your own, to source Salesforce CMS images to Pardot email marketing content and templates.

What You Need

Backend Setup Salesforce Setup

  • Setup a Community
  • Make sure if using an existing community that it is based on the most up-to-date Lightning template.
  • CDN (optional)
  • Enable Libraries by going to Salesforce Files in Setup | Salesforce Files | General Settings.

Content Admin or Salesforce admin AND ensure that in Setup, the user profile has Visible selected for Salesforce CMS and CMS Workspaces is Default On in the Tabs Settings.

AND Create Content Workspace administrative permissions must be selected AND Access Libraries must be selected in the system permissions of the user profile

Permissions

Go to Setup and create a Perm Set. This perm set will have the access to create and edit CMS for internal users in Salesforce/Community Workspaces.

  • Go to Setup and go to Permission Sets
  • Create a New Permission Set
  • Go to Apps and set Salesforce CMS App Visible.
  • Go to Objects on the same Perm Set, and ADD access to the CMS Channels, CMS Workspaces, CMS Home, and CMS Experiences with Default On for Tabs Settings
  • Under App Permissions, select access Libraries
  • Save
  • Assign Perm Set

CMS Workspace Setup

Now we want to access that App we gave ourselves the perms set to see. Just a heads-up, once we make a CMS workspace, we can’t delete it.

  • In Salesforce, use the App Launcher, AKA waffle, to find and open the Salesforce CMS App (only in Lightning)
  • Click Add Workspace
    • Add a name and description
  • Add one or more channels to the workspace, this is how the workspace is shared, it an be with a Community or via perm set or Commerce Cloud or Heroku
  • This can be updated later as well if unsure
    • Select who is going to be a contributor to the Workspace, this can be internal users or internal groups
      • This can be updated later as well if unsure
    • Add your Languages – you MUST select the default language at a minimum
  • Click done

Workspace Setup

 

Topics

  • Access the Community Workspace for the Community just created
  • Click Content Management (the hashtag) to get to CMS and Topics
  • Click Topics at the top of the page in the Navigation
  • Create a topic or two of your choice,
  • For those topics click Enable for content setting
  • Save

Create a CMS Record

To Create a Native CMS Record you’ll go into Salesforce proper and return to the CMS Home Tab in Lightning. This tab is only visible in LIghtning.

  • From CMS Home, select the Workspace you created/want to create content for and enter the CMS Workspace.
  • Once you select ‘Add Content‘, you’ll choose which type of content to create
  • Once selected, fill in the Content data for the CMS Record Details

Publish and Prep CMS

Now that. you have your CMS record in the workspace, you are almost ready to go, but your record still needs to be published in the related locations for that Workspace…

Go back to your community workspace where you created the Topics under Setup – Digital Experiences – Workspace – Content Management

You’ll see your published article here on the page for CMS content now. To have it show in components dynamically, you’ll want to assign a Topic. Click on your article to assign. This allows you to automagically add your articles to CMS Collections with criteria based on topics.

To the “Collections Tab!” (one over in the Content Management area). Here we can create our criteria.

  • Select “New”
  • Add a name that is descriptive to what the collection is (this must be unique)
  • You then have 2 options, Manually or Conditionally. Conditionally gives you the option to. use criteria, select that one
  • Now your two options are to meet all criteria or any criteria, choose wisely. You can use Topic, Title, and Publish Date (including relative dates) for Collection Criteria.

CMS Components

CMS Collection

Used to show an Automatically or Manually curated Collection of Multiple items

  • Can be used on any type of page, Standard, Object, content, however CRM CMS cannot be the record detail just used via a collection on a detail page
  • Can be used with Native CMS or Salesforce CRM CMS
  • Collection Layouts: Has 4 different Collection Layouts: Grid, Carousel, Strip and Slideshow
  • Collection Settings are used for:
    • Button configuration for the whole component
    • Number of Columns Displayed
    • Number of Rows Displayed
    • Title Location, If there will be a title displayed above the component what will the title be?
  • Content Layout: Has 3 different Content Layouts: Banner, Title, Card
    • The assignment of fields to the component fields, either from the CMS Record of the Salesforce Object record
  • Once the layout is selected, you then select which fields to map within the CMS Collection component. You won’t map every field every time, only use the fields you need. Also, you may have you mix and match how you map, due to how fields display.

Collection Field Tips

Metadata fields 1 & 2 are to display any fields from the record detail you choose, however they show the formatting tags (<b>, <p>, etc). In other words, if using a rich text field, you might want to use Subheading instead.

Flag is best kept to a 1-2 word phrase, such as ‘New’, ‘Sale’, ‘Example’, etc. and is only able to be placed in a few locations on the record.

Fun Pro Tip: You can redirect your link to go to anywhere vs the record detail when clicking for the detail page, Eg if using the Document type and wanting to just download vs redirect to a new page.

FUN PRO TIP: REDIRECTION How do you redirect the link, you ask? Well, let me show you how! In the Collection Component, scroll to the “Links” section. From here, you can set what each value links to with another value off the record. You need to add urls for downloads in a field Eg document or image url do have the record download. Once you have that, to download, I set the URL for the document in the Source field, the use the Source as the Component Field Link field under “Links” and Viola! This is a great option to download vs going to a record detail.

Detail Components

CMS Single Item

This component is used to display a single Native CMS record at a time. It does not display Salesforce CRM CMS or CMS Connect records, only the Native records. Again, Native CMS is the CMS created within Salesforce in the CMS Home tab. You will want to have a Native CMS record created and published for the workspace that applies to the Community you are working in before adding a CMS Single Item component.

Similar to the CMS Collection component, they are great CMS Single Items, because they work on non-Content Detail pages, they have individually assigned field mappings and image fields from the component, and you can do some great custom content types and expand your options.

So how does this component work? Where are these crazy options I speak of… Well here are some of those deets (and remember, before adding the CMS Single Item to the page make sure you have a record created and published in CMS Home within Salesforce that applies to the Community.):

  • First and foremost make sure you have a Native CMS Record Created in Salesforce within the CMS Home tab
  • Within the Community Workspace

CMS Single Item (Detail)

CMS Types

The Native CMS comes with 3 out of the box CMS Content Types, News, Image, and Document. These three different types of Native CMS have different files and functionality available. They are varied to help you with

News – Used to display any Articles, announcements, etc. The Images uploaded to News CMS records are created as CMS Image records, leading to 2 records being created each time.

Image – Used for banners in the sidebar or as the image with News CMS Content Records, each News CMS record that has an image, also has an Image record.

Document – Lets you upload a file or input a URL to share a document alone, with just an image with it.

Custom CMS Content Types – Can be created via the API and inserted into the ManagedContentType object. Great for creating a Blog, Events, or Video content Type. Few things to keep in mind:

  • You can have up to 20 active Content Types in addition to your out of the box, for more, contact Salesforce to increase the limit.
  • Each content Type can have up to 15 notes (fields)
  • You’ll want to make a Name/Title field to recognize your content
  • If working in a multi-language situation, you’ll want to make sure to determine if the fields are translatable and if so select isLocalizable
  • Your slug (URL ending for the record) is system added
  • You can only add Content Types via the API out of the box and the custom app
  • If adding URL links make sure they are in your CORS settings

CMS Apps

The CMS Content Type Creator app helps you create new Custom Content types (such as adding Blog, Event or Video to your existing News, Image, and Document 😉) so that you can have your own custom layouts, fields, and CMS content design for your articles.

Gotchas

If you run into issues, here are some tips to help you out.

  • What exactly is a ‘Collection‘?
    • Collections group and organize pieces of Content, with Content being either CMS records, CMS Connect Records, or Salesforce CRM Records. Consider them a prefiltered list of data for you that has different options for the layouts. 🙂

Troubleshooting Issues

  • Issue: External users (Authenticated) are unable to see your content.
    • Check your external sharing model For for the User on the object is Public Read Only if using Salesforce CRM CMS.
    • If using Native CMS ensure they have access to CMS records
      • Then check if the article is in the Content area of the Workspace for the Community
      • If not in the workspace the check under the internal CMS Home tab for the CMS Workspace visibility settings
    • Then check in the Community Workspace – Administration – Preferences you have selected access to CMS.
    • Alternatively, enable Portal User Visibility or Site User Visibility as appropriate In the community Workspace- Administration – Preferences
  • Issue: Guest users can’t see CMS content.
    • Confirm site (and relevant pages) have public access turned on for guest user.
      • Ensure Let guest uses view asset files on public and login pages is enabled under General in Experience Workspaces | Administration | Preferences.
      • To make the site available to the public, in Experience Builder, go to Settings | General and enable Public can access the site under Public Access
      • To make only a specific page public (if your site is private), in Experience Builder, open the page’s properties and select Public under Page Access.
    • Confirm that the guest user profile has Read access for the Salesforce objects that are part of a CRM collection.
      • With Secure guest user access enabled, create a criteria-based sharing rule on the standard object for guest users.
    • Although the Salesforce CMS app is available in sandbox orgs, you can’t migrate CMS Collections to a production org. We recommend that you use the CMS app in your production org to create content that you plan to use beyond testing.

More Info

  • CMS workspaces share the content you create in them with associated channels. Content is curated and made live to your users on a site by site basis.
  • Issue: Content not available for Collection
    • Check the Workspace has the collection within
    • Alternatively, enable Portal User Visibility or Site User Visibility as appropriate In the community Workspace- Administration – Preferences
  • In Salesforce, from the App Launcher, find and open Salesforce CMS.
  • NOTE Enabling Secure guest user access is mandatory starting with the Winter ’21 release.
  • To use your Salesforce CMS workspace content with B2C Commerce Page Designer, see Connect Salesforce CMS to Page Designer.

excerpt.rendered: Out of the box you you have 3 types of CMS, native CMS is one of those 3. Learn all about it from how to create articles, use cases, and why use Native CMS.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce CRM CMS
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: We've talked CMS Connect, Native CMS, now hear all about Salesforce CRM CMS and the wins you get using it in your community!

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect for WordPress
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: So you want to connect your WordPress site to your Community? Here's how it's done with CMS Connect.

jetpack-related-posts.title: CMS Connect 18 Updates
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: My experience at Connections 18 and updates to CMS Connect for your Lightning Community, learn all about it here!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Dreamforce 18 – The Thursday of Presentations
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: This Dreamforce was c-razy!! Not only was it my first Dreamforce as an MVP, but it was also the Dreamforce of back to back action for me. Here's a bit about my #DF18 adventure...

jetpack-related-posts.title: Community Sharing Part 1: Sharing Sets – Your First Step in Sharing
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Sharing Sets are an amazing superpower that comes with your Communities. They are a way to share with Community License types and Community users. Keep in mind, this type of security and sharing is only available for your community users, it is not available to share with internal users.

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce Events 2020
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: The Salesforce Events 2020 is live!! That's right Ohana, it wouldn't be my blog if I wasn't talking about events and how we connect and get together as humans.  For real, we get out from behind the keyboard, and even leave the HOUSE!!! I know, it's crazy, but for Ohana,…
